instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN_L: What is PCH_INTVRMEN_L? PCH_INTVRMEN_L is a signal that stands for Internal Voltage Regulator Enable. When pulled high, this signal enables the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must be pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power, no green light
threads.message:
Hello!

I have this mac that does not turn on, does not turn on any led on the magsafe and no fan. (I already rewrite bios)
No corrosion/liquid damage

measurements:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.59v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.485v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0.013v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.355v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0v

When trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, nothing happens.

Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power, no green light
threads.message:
Put back original BIOS; is not related with Magsafe light.
SPI chip usually requires <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>; why touch it, if is not even powered?

Post MLB code (maybe <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>/3115), not DCIN.
Then we can give you more information.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power, no green light
threads.message:
Edited: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A (Sorry..)

Rewrited original bios

What can i check now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power, no green light
threads.message:
In this board, <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> is powered by <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> indeed; however, not related with missing Magsafe light.

Check <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWRMEN</SIGNAL> and the 4 (four) PCH's RTC signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power, no green light
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.48v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> = 3.226v

<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.347v
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.347v
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> = 3.062v
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN_L</SIGNAL> = 3.256v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5v
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.482v

apparently everything is ok, what else can I check?

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power, no green light
threads.message:
Chek <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>.
Be sure to use 85W original charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power, no green light
threads.message:
I only have 60w original charger, its a problem?

<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.40v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> - 0v

PS: with lab PSU, the green light sometimes turns on and stays on, sometimes turns on and off in a few seconds (without pattern).
With original supply, rarely turns on the green light, but when it lights up stays on for 7 seconds and off.

however, now I plugged in the original charger (60w) and the green light stays on ever .. !? (but never turned on)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power, no green light
threads.message:
60W charger is not original for this machine!
This board will not start with other charger alone, than 85W.
Unelss charged battery is plugged in.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power, no green light
threads.message:
Lucas, please have a look at this video. If you don't have much time, I suggest to start watching from 5:10.
[MEDIA=youtube]B3w8nwyrdYw[/MEDIA]
